Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learnt to research a paper, to produce a claim that is original, corrective and contestable. I learnt to really think about my argument and my own motivations for making them, which I feel can really influence their strengths.
I basically learned how to write well and better understand where I needed to improve from Robinson's feedback.
The course was good preparation to write academic papers on nonfiction topics at a collegiate level.
I learned how to write properly.
This course has NO weaknesses. Don't think. Just Take it.  Professor Robinson does a marvellous job of giving you feedback and genuinely wants to help you improve your writing.

A major strength was the feedback I received on each of my drafts. I do wish that we were able to submit the full first draft of the final essay and obtain feedback on that as many of the other sections did. Besides that, there were not necessarily any other weaknesses from what I could tell.
This course is very well taught and executed. The flow of the material and the assignments was very fluid and manageable.

The discussion based seminar was engaging and the class provided a lot of opportunities to get feedback. It might be better if the whole class participated in discussions rather than just a few students.
Some essays had vague guidelines. It might be by design but really tripped me up in the beginning.

YES. It is an amazing, thought-provoking, entertaining, and extremely rewarding course. Do take it if you can get the chance. You'll learn so much much about writing, and about finding and polishing your own voice

I would. Censorship and the Arts is a hidden gem among all of the thirty-something 114 sections. In general, Robinson was relatively understanding and flexible in terms of deadlines, and listened to student feedback fairly well. Overall, he was great prof who designed a great course, and I definitely recommend his section.
Yes TR is an amazing professor, workload is light and you learn a lot

Yes, of course. If you can take 114 with Professor Robinson, do it. He's an amazing professor, so kindhearted and in love with what he does. It's not a terrible writing credit by any stretch of the imagination.
Yes, it is a good course if ou want to become more confident in writing.
Yes. The professor was incredibly funny and knowledgeable. You'll have a good time.
